repnme.cdata!: Bolivia - Environment, Industry and Mining Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Environment, Industry and Mining
            Project for Bolivia had the following ratings:  the outcome
            was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory.  Lessons
            learned indicate that the project has shown problems related
            to the interference of political cycles in project
            implementation as a consequence of the change in
            administrations and political, economic and social unrest.
            The long implementation cycle suffered from a loss of the
            authorities interest and commitment in project objectives
            and execution.  Among the lessons learned are the following:
            (1) Project objectives and components should be simple and
            focused; (2) A comprehensive, rigorous and realistic
            assessment of risks, in terms of country capacity,
            institutional effectiveness, fiduciary aspects, economic and
            financial viability, as well as other exogenous factors
            should be completed, and mitigating strategies and action
            plans to address them as/if they occur, should be
            incorporated to the project design; (3) The team should put
            in place mechanisms to strengthen weak areas and make sure
            that the World Bank Procurement, Financial Management,
            Disbursement guidelines and procedures are fully understood
            by the Borrower; (4) A good monitoring and evaluation system
            with focus on results and outcomes should be an integral
            part of the project design; (5) Bank management should
            ensure continuity in supervision teams to avoid
            interruptions or delays with implementation; (6) Bank
            Supervision of the project should be continuous and
            supported by proper budgets and skill mix; and (7) The
            project team should work with the counterparts to ensure
            that the beneficiaries and stakeholders at large remain
            involved at the project execution stage, so that the project
            does not lose its priority and visibility.

repnme.cdata!: Bolivia - Environment, Industry and Mining Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Environment, Industry and Mining
            Project will: 1) support the implementation and refinement
            of a regulatory framework to assure that privately-led
            mining and industrial activities grow in a more
            environmentally-friendly fashion; 2) help remediate
            contamination from past mining activities for which the
            state accepts liability, including remediation activities
            that help facilitate private investment in the mining
            sector; and 3) assist in attracting non-project resources
            for investments which are not eligible for financing under
            the project in mining communities, in order to address
            urgent environmental problems, e.g. for potable water and
            sanitation. The project will include the following
            components: 1) studies to support the development of the
            regulatory framework, which will include basic data
            collection and policy development implementation; 2)
            laboratory upgrading for the implementation of a program to
            foster development of credible laboratory testing services
            in Bolivia; 3) remediation investments, which will be done
            on a pilot basis and only for those eligible subprojects
            comprising priority environmental management measures; and
            4) technical assistance and training to support
            environmental management in mining.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Sectoral environmental assessment
            of the mining and industrial (manufacturing) sectors

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the summary of the environmental
            assessment (EA) of the mining and industrial
            (manuafacturing) sectors in Bolivia. The EA served as the
            basis for preparing the proposed Environment, Industry and
            Mining Project supported by IDA. The project: a) supports
            the implementation and refinement of a regulatory framework
            to assure that privately-led mining and industrial
            activities grow in a more sustainable fashion; and b) help
            remediate pollution stocks for which the Government will
            accept environmental liability, including as a result of
            agreements reached with private investors in the mining and
            hydrocarbons sectors under the Capitalization Program.
            Environmental audits for major mining and hydrocarbon
            properties are either underway or will be commissioned
            shortly, and are expected to be completed in 1995.
            Presently, the mining and industrial sectors seem to pose
            relatively little threat to the primary areas of high
            ecological sensitivity, although the baseline data is very
            limited. The most immediate concern is alluvial gold mining
            in the Amazon. Also, industrial activity in Santa Cruz and
            Cochabamba are of potential concern because these also drain
            into the Amazon.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Sectoral environmental assessment
            of the mining and industrial (manufacturing) sectors

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the summary of the environmental
            assessment (EA) of the mining and industrial
            (manuafacturing) sectors in Bolivia. The EA served as the
            basis for preparing the proposed Environment, Industry and
            Mining Project supported by IDA. The project: a) supports
            the implementation and refinement of a regulatory framework
            to assure that privately-led mining and industrial
            activities grow in a more sustainable fashion; and b) help
            remediate pollution stocks for which the Government will
            accept environmental liability, including as a result of
            agreements reached with private investors in the mining and
            hydrocarbons sectors under the Capitalization Program.
            Environmental audits for major mining and hydrocarbon
            properties are either underway or will be commissioned
            shortly, and are expected to be completed in 1995.
            Presently, the mining and industrial sectors seem to pose
            relatively little threat to the primary areas of high
            ecological sensitivity, although the baseline data is very
            limited. The most immediate concern is alluvial gold mining
            in the Amazon. Also, industrial activity in Santa Cruz and
            Cochabamba are of potential concern because these also drain
            into the Amazon.
